Whyleare great Zeus from the Olympian throne</br>Look'd downe, and mortalls thus bespeaking cryed,</br>"Lo here the Worlde!  take itt, it is youre owne,</br>And soe yee brotherlye the same dyvyde,</br>Tis your's for aye, whatever chaunce betyde."</br>Ne young, ne old, but then incontinent,</br>To winne him joyaunce and fair fortune hide;</br>Flowers and fruites ywis the labourer hent</br>Whiles chasyng through the grove the youthe aye fearlesse went.

The merchaunt then he store-houses 'gan fille,</br>His barnes the farmer, and his vattes the prieste;</br>The king yspake, "Lette eache man have his wille,</br>And take what lykes him beste from this rich feaste,</br>So shalle my taxes bee stille more yncreased."</br>Now when long time all had dyvyded beene,</br>Appeared the Poet from the distaunt easte:</br>Pardie!  ne ought but had its Lord, I ween,</br>And in no place around could aught for him be seen!

"Now woe betyde, and am I then alone,</br>Of all withaulten from thy souvenaunce,</br>Whom thou as deareste sonne whyleare didst owne!"</br>Soe burste hee forth in cryes of doloraunce,</br>And at Jove's feet 'gan weep his sad mischaunce.</br>"Mee blame not," said the God, "that thou delayed,</br>From thy fonde londe of dreames betymes t' advaunce,</br>Where tarried thou whiles mortalls forby made,</br>Dyvysion of the Earthe?"  "With thee," the Poet saide.

"Upon thy face resplendant hung myne eyne,</br>Thy Heaven's harmonie entraunced my ear,</br>Oh, pardon!  that amiddes thy lighte divine</br>My soule yrapt, forgat the earthlie sphere!"</br>"Deare sonne," quoth Jove, "how may I soothe thy dreare?</br>Chase, market, harvest, ne ought else I see,</br>Are longer mine to give; then wilt thou here</br>With mee in Heaven abide, I promise thee</br>Henceforth, whene'er thou come, the entraunce shall be free."</br>
